´

Bill Willis

Morocco’s Finest Aesthete

He had an extraordinary imagination.

Pierre Bergé
Co-founder Yves Saint-Laurent
Bill Willis (1937-2009) was the father of Moroccan style interior design. He studied and rescued the old techniques of craftsmen from North Africa and gave them a new life by daring to change the paradigms of this ancient style. His life was as interesting as his creations. We tracked down Bill's friends, members of the bohemian high society, in Marrakech, London, Paris and New York to share his story.

He looks for perfection, and I believe he was a genius.

Mohamed Zkhiri
Yacout Restaurant

I was astonished by his capacity for artificial fuelling. He liked quivering with sensations all the time.

Christopher Gibbs
Antique Dealer & Collector

He could be ruthless with people he either felt were tacky, dumb or not conscious enough.

Marian McEvoy
Journalist & Author

He could be outrageous at points but he also had very strong principles, that he often couldn’t live up to.

Madison Cox
Director of Fondation
YSL - Pierre Bergé

He was in touch with himself and creation, a confidence in what he thought was right, good and beautiful.

Nicolette Meeres
Painter
